awd_titl_txt: Collaborating Across Boundaries to Engage Undergraduates in STEM Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by studying how interdisciplinary collaborations in the classroom can improve STEM learning for all undergraduates. The increasingly interdisciplinary and complex issues facing our society requires diverse, STEM-literate experts from a range of fields who can work and solve problems in collaboration. Addressing this national need requires innovative, research-based teaching practices that retain students and improve STEM learning. This project will expand, improve, and study an innovative curricular model in which two undergraduate courses from different disciplines are taught in coordination. The instructors, goals, and outcomes of each course will be distinct, but the courses will be connected by a science-focused project that is developed through an active collaboration with a community partner. By the end of the project, 750 students will have experienced this model, allowing for a comprehensive evaluation of its effectiveness. Furthermore, over a dozen faculty members in different disciplines will be trained in using effective strategies for teaching STEM concepts. This project will contribute to educational strategies that can produce the STEM-literate workforce needed to tackle the pressing interdisciplinary problems of our time. 

This project draws from project-based, collaborative, and community-engaged learning to design STEM classroom experiences that improve learning outcomes and retention for all undergraduates. This project will carry out a non-comparative group, quasi-experimental design to answer five research questions: (1) Does the model identify best practices that allow faculty members to harmonize cultures across disciplines and between the classroom and the community? (2) Is the model an effective method of improving undergraduate STEM education across different disciplines, and for which disciplines is it most effective? (3) What combinations of courses are the most effective for improving STEM learning? (4) Does the model improve STEM learning among historically underrepresented students? (5) What community engaged learning projects are best for improving learning outcomes for STEM and non-STEM students? To answer these questions, this project will support the formation of partnerships between instructors from three main disciplinary groups: STEM; Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences; and non-STEM disciplines such as the humanities and performing arts. STEM student learning outcomes will be assessed using multiple measures, including student self-assessment, faculty assessment, and pre-to-post performance on a standardized instrument. This project will provide the foundational information needed for future implementation of the model at other institutions, so that the impact of the proposed work may expand to STEM workforce development at a broader scale.  This Engaged Student Learning project is supported by the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), which supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all undergraduate students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Collaborating Across Boundaries (CAB) to Engage Undergraduate Students in STEM Learning project (NSF Award #1914869) was an initiative to scale, test and refine a pedagogical model for interdisciplinary, community-engaged collaborations aimed at boosting learning in STEM, collaboration, and civic engagement. Nearly two dozen faculty and 1,135 students at The College of New Jersey (TCNJ), and 18 community partners participated in the project between 2019 and 2023. Classes from two disciplines collaborate with a community partner to address a community-identified problem. The pedagogical model draws upon previous research, most notably, the Collaborating Across Boundaries to To Engage Undergraduates in Computational Thinking (CABECT) project (NSF Award #1141170). The CAB project demonstrates that collaboration between STEM and non-STEM courses has great potential to change how non-scientists learn about scientific methods and knowledge, and how scientists understand the social, ethical, and moral impacts of science on society. The model helps prepare students for the complex issues they will be required to address in the workplace.  

The five focal research questions, and summaries of our findings, based on qualitative and quantitative assessments, are discussed below.

Did the CAB  model identify best practices for interdisciplinary, community-engaged pedagogies? 

The effectiveness of the CAB model had more to do with support for faculty and implementation logistics than with the content of the classes. With appropriate training the CAB model could be implemented by professors with no previous experience,  although professors who repeated their collaborations were able to focus on higher order pedagogical concerns rather than on logistics.  

A joint ?shell? in the learning management system enabled communication and community across sections, and collaborative grading. To address potential privacy concerns related to the Federal Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) students were informed of the collaboration during registration for courses; these warnings may have depressed enrollments in some courses.   

Many students were initially skeptical, and assumed that collaboration required additional work. Clear communication and course-based learning goals helped alleviate these concerns, as did dedicating class time to the CAB projects and providing feedback not linked to interim grades. When students embraced the collaborations, they overwhelmingly found that the experience was beneficial to their learning, and helped build their resumes. 

Interdisciplinary collaboration cannot be fully standardized and routinized.  While the workloads for project grading and planning are shared between collaborating professors, CAB projects require considerable time for planning and project management, even for experienced professors. Coordination with community partners must occur early, to integrate the project clearly into course learning goals and to establish the project timeline. Students benefit from exercises that foster flexibility and communication skills, from efforts to build community within and across classes, mechanisms for accountability, and clear deliverables and due dates. 

Is the CAB model an effective method of improving undergraduate STEM education across different majors, and for which majors is it most effective?  

It has been almost impossible to assess how innovations to the higher education curriculum have changed student learning outcomes in the last four years, given the global disruption of the COVID-19 pandemic. Even so, our data indicate that regardless of class, semester, and instruction mode, students assess their own scientific skills more positively after participation in a CAB project. Statistical testing found few consistent differences between STEM and non-STEM students on subjective and objective measures of scientific learning. 

What combination of courses are most effective for STEM learning in the CAB model? (major vs. non-major; STEM vs. non-STEM)?

Objective measures did not produce meaningful or statistically significant differences between collaborations from various disciplinary group pairings. We conclude that the CAB model benefits students regardless of major, and collaborations produce similar benefits regardless of the disciplines involved in the partnership.    

Is the CAB model effective for improving STEM learning among historically underrepresented student groups?

Our results are inconclusive whether the CAB model differentially benefited historically underrepresented student groups. We have some evidence to suggest that there are no robust differences between students in terms of gender, race, ethnicity, or academic major, but data from the last four years reflect the effect of the COVID-19 pandemic. Even after returning to campus full-time in Fall 2021, CAB projects remained mostly remote; the continued disruptions are likely more acute in students from groups historically underrepresented in higher education.

What types of combined community engaged learning (CEL)  projects are best for improving learning outcomes for STEM and non-STEM majors?

The COVID-19 pandemic forced all CAB projects to use ?indirect service? since we were denied site visits. Indirect service allows projects to be completed off-site, with community partner participation in project design and feedback throughout the semester. Improvements in the school?s remote communication infrastructure facilitated collaboration with community partners. Indirect service is well-suited for CAB projects since the focus is on applying course content to better serve the needs of community partners.


 

 


Last Modified: 10/11/2023
Modified by: Sarah M Pulimood
